items.synopsis: Adrian's been held for years in solitary confinement without a release date, living with an intellectual disability and chromosomal disorder. The public has never seen how he lives until now.

title.children: 'Get me out of here': Adrian's been pacing this caged area for more than a decade

image.altText: Four people stand on top of a truck, waving Egyptian flags at the Rafah border crossing.

items.synopsis: The Rafah border crossing between Egypt and Gaza will be reopened to allow foreign nationals out of the embattled Palestinian city, according to the US Secretary of State. Follow live.

title.children: Border crossing between Egypt and Palestinian territory set to reopen, allowing evacuations and aid

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ABC's global affairs correspondent John Lyons has been reporting from Israel for the past week along with Nick Dole, Tom Joyner, Riley Stuart and Orly Halpern and our contacts in Gaza. John Lyons will be joining the blog later today to answer your questions about this war. You can share your questions by hitting the blue leave a comment button at the top of this stream. We'll pass on your questions to John who'll join us from 7:30pm AEDT. In the meantime, here's John's latest column on the biggest winner of this war.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Do you have questions about the Israel-Gaza war? Ask our correspondent John Lyons

featuredLink.title: The biggest winner of the Israel-Gaza war may just be Vladimir Putin

children.content: The ABC's global affairs correspondent John Lyons has been reporting from Israel for the past week along with Nick Dole, Tom Joyner, Riley Stuart and Orly Halpern and our contacts in Gaza.
John Lyons will be joining the blog later today to answer your questions about this war. You can share your questions by hitting the blue leave a comment button at the top of this stream.
We'll pass on your questions to John who'll join us from 7:30pm AEDT.
In the meantime, here's John's latest column on the biggest winner of this war.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There are plans to open the Rafah border crossing between Gaza and Egypt to allow aid into the region. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken has said "Rafah will be reopened" to allow foreign nationals out, but we don't know the exact timeline yet. A spokesperson for the Israel Defense Forces says Hamas stopped the border from opening. "I know there have been discussions [about opening Rafah, but] I cannot yet confirm they have been fruitful," Jonathan Conricus said in a Twitter Q & A. "The day before yesterday we tried to get foreign nationals out of Gaza. That failed because Hamas refused to open the gate. Hamas don't want people to evacuate from northern Gaza to the south. They are not allowing the opening of the gates from Rafah to Egypt."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: IDF accuses Hamas of refusing to allow Rafah border crossing to open

children.content: There are plans to open the Rafah border crossing between Gaza and Egypt to allow aid into the region.
US Secretary of State Antony Blinken has said "Rafah will be reopened" to allow foreign nationals out, but we don't know the exact timeline yet.
A spokesperson for the Israel Defense Forces says Hamas stopped the border from opening.
"I know there have been discussions [about opening Rafah, but] I cannot yet confirm they have been fruitful," Jonathan Conricus said in a Twitter Q
A.

"The day before yesterday we tried to get foreign nationals out of Gaza. That failed because Hamas refused to open the gate. Hamas don't want people to evacuate from northern Gaza to the south. They are not allowing the opening of the gates from Rafah to Egypt."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hundreds of metric tonnes of aid from several countries have been held up in Egypt's Sinai Peninsula for days pending a deal for its safe delivery to Gaza and the evacuation of some foreign passport holders through the Rafah crossing. "Rafah will be reopened. We’re putting in place with the United Nations, with Egypt, with Israel, with others, a mechanism by which to get the assistance in and to get it to people who need it," US Secretary of State Antony Blinken said after a meeting with Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi on Sunday. Blinken did not give a specific time for the crossing to reopen. Veteran US diplomat David Satterfield, appointed on Sunday as a special envoy for Middle East humanitarian issues, will arrive in Egypt on Monday to work out the details, Blinken said. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rafah border crossing in Egypt will be reopened, says US Secretary of State Antony Blinken

children.content: Hundreds of metric tonnes of aid from several countries have been held up in Egypt's Sinai Peninsula for days pending a deal for its safe delivery to Gaza and the evacuation of some foreign passport holders through the Rafah crossing.

"Rafah will be reopened. We’re putting in place with the United Nations, with Egypt, with Israel, with others, a mechanism by which to get the assistance in and to get it to people who need it," US Secretary of State Antony Blinken said after a meeting with Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi on Sunday.

Blinken did not give a specific time for the crossing to reopen. Veteran US diplomat David Satterfield, appointed on Sunday as a special envoy for Middle East humanitarian issues, will arrive in Egypt on Monday to work out the details, Blinken said.

props.alt: An image of trucks lined up outside the Rafah crossing

children.content: Trucks carrying humanitarian aid to Palestinians wait for the Rafah border crossing to open
(Reuters: Stringer)

image.altText: Peter Dutton in the House of Representatives.

items.synopsis: Follow our live updates on the fallout from the Voice to Parliament referendum's defeat on Monday, October 16, 2023.

title.children: Coalition to review promise for constitutional recognition vote, Dutton says Australians 'probably over' referendum process

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton used the opening question in federal parliament Question Time today to call on the prime minister to apologise for taking the Voice to Parliament to a referendum "against advice", as well as for inflation and power price rises. In a later series of questions, Deputy Opposition Leader Sussan Ley described the referendum as "divisive and incompetently managed", asking why Mr Albanese he had focused on "inner-city elites": "Why did he refuse to hold a constitutional convention? Why didn't he make the effort to achieve bipartisanship? Why did he waste $450 million of taxpayers' money? Why did he proceed when it was clear his vanity project was going so disastrously wrong?" In response, Mr Albanese said: "Let's be very clear here about what occurred. There was a constitutional convention. There was one established under the former government in 2017. After a process that the former government established under Tony Abbott when he established a process, a working group, who are charged with coming back to the Australian people about what form constitutional recognition should take. "That was after John Howard, of course, and every other leader since promised to promote constitutional recognition. "After a process in 2017, First Nations people through the Uluru Statement from the Heart, those eloquent 440 words, issued an invitation to Australians to walk with them on the form of recognition they sought. That was recognition through a Voice. There were then processes established, including under the former government, The Calma Langton Report and other processes, the joint committee chaired by Patrick Dodson and Julian Leeser, to progress this issue. "I said before the election on a range of occasions, as did both leaders, Scott Morrison and Bill Shorten prior to 2019, that there would be an advance on these issues. I was at Garma when the minister for Indigenous affairs, Ken Wyatt, said there would be a referendum held. I was there in 2019. "What occurred was that I fulfilled that commitment that I made. It was not out of convenience, it was out of conviction. I believe that when you make a commitment, including a commitment to Indigenous people, that it should be fulfilled. "And, I make this point — across remote areas dominated by Indigenous communities, Yes recorded massive support."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Opposition attacks PM for 'divisive' referendum

children.content: Opposition Leader
Peter Dutton

used the opening question in federal parliament Question Time today to call on the prime minister to apologise for taking the Voice to Parliament to a referendum "against advice", as well as for inflation and power price rises.
In a later series of questions, Deputy Opposition Leader
Sussan Ley
described the referendum as "divisive and incompetently managed", asking why Mr Albanese he had focused on "inner-city elites":

"Why did he refuse to hold a constitutional convention? Why didn't he make the effort to achieve bipartisanship? Why did he waste $450 million of taxpayers' money? Why did he proceed when it was clear his vanity project was going so disastrously wrong?"
In response, Mr Albanese said:

"Let's be very clear here about what occurred. There was a constitutional convention. There was one established under the former government in 2017. After a process that the former government established under Tony Abbott when he established a process, a working group, who are charged with coming back to the Australian people about what form constitutional recognition should take.
"That was after John Howard, of course, and every other leader since promised to promote constitutional recognition.

"After a process in 2017, First Nations people through the Uluru Statement from the Heart, those eloquent 440 words, issued an invitation to Australians to walk with them on the form of recognition they sought. That was recognition through a Voice. There were then processes established, including under the former government, The Calma Langton Report and other processes, the joint committee chaired by Patrick Dodson and Julian Leeser, to progress this issue.

"I said before the election on a range of occasions, as did both leaders, Scott Morrison and Bill Shorten prior to 2019, that there would be an advance on these issues. I was at Garma when the minister for Indigenous affairs, Ken Wyatt, said there would be a referendum held. I was there in 2019.

"What occurred was that I fulfilled that commitment that I made. It was not out of convenience, it was out of conviction. I believe that when you make a commitment, including a commitment to Indigenous people, that it should be fulfilled.
"And, I make this point — across remote areas dominated by Indigenous communities, Yes recorded massive support."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Mr Albanese continued answering the question, saying he would continue to consult with Indigenous Australians about what the way forward would be following the referendum proposal's defeat. "Because the issues that we sought to address have not gone away, and nor have the people of goodwill and good heart who want to address them," he said. "We will address them with hope in our heart and with faith in each other and with kindness towards one another. Walking together in a spirit of unity and healing. "The great Australian story goes back some 65,000 years. We have an opportunity as parliamentarians to write the next chapter. As government, we have a responsibility to write the next chapter as well. A chapter that sees the gap closing because we know that only four out of 19 targets are on track as we speak. Australians know, Australians know that that is not good enough and that is why we must seek to achieve that change."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'The issues have not gone away': PM says of closing the gap

children.content: Anthony Albanese says the government needs to find other ways to close the gap.
(ABC News)
Mr Albanese continued answering the question, saying he would continue to consult with Indigenous Australians about what the way forward would be following the referendum proposal's defeat.
"Because the issues that we sought to address have not gone away, and nor have the people of goodwill and good heart who want to address them," he said.
"We will address them with hope in our heart and with faith in each other and with kindness towards one another. Walking together in a spirit of unity and healing.

"The great Australian story goes back some 65,000 years. We have an opportunity as parliamentarians to write the next chapter. As government, we have a responsibility to write the next chapter as well. A chapter that sees the gap closing because we know that only four out of 19 targets are on track as we speak. Australians know, Australians know that that is not good enough and that is why we must seek to achieve that change."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese addressed the referendum defeat in question time this afternoon, after receiving a question from Lingiari Labor MP Marion Scrymgour asking Mr Albanese what his message was to Australians following the result. After thanking Ms Scrymgour for her work in remote communities in Central Australia, Mr Albanese responded: "Now, the referendum on Saturday was not the result that I had hoped for. But I respect the decision and the democratic process that produced it. We can make, in this country, the big decisions peacefully and as equals. We know that referendums are hard, that is why only eight of 45 have passed. None without bipartisan support," he said. "And I certainly accept responsibility for the decisions that I have taken. This was a constitutional change asked for, requested, and imitation from Indigenous Australians. I accepted that invitation and I followed through on the commitments that I made. Australians did not accept the constitutional change that was proposed. But no-one is arguing for the status quo. No-one can say that just keep on doing the same thing is good enough for Australia. "What has occurred in recent times is now a much greater national awareness. We need to channel that into a national purpose to find the answers. The referendum was about listening to people and about getting better outcomes. And these principles will continue to guide me."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'No one is arguing for the status quo': PM responds to referendum result in parliament

children.content: Prime Minister
Anthony Albanese
addressed the referendum defeat in question time this afternoon, after receiving a question from Lingiari Labor MP
Marion Scrymgour
asking Mr Albanese what his message was to Australians following the result.
After thanking Ms Scrymgour for her work in remote communities in Central Australia, Mr Albanese responded:

"Now, the referendum on Saturday was not the result that I had hoped for. But I respect the decision and the democratic process that produced it. We can make, in this country, the big decisions peacefully and as equals. We know that referendums are hard, that is why only eight of 45 have passed. None without bipartisan support," he said.

"And I certainly accept responsibility for the decisions that I have taken. This was a constitutional change asked for, requested, and imitation from Indigenous Australians. I accepted that invitation and I followed through on the commitments that I made. Australians did not accept the constitutional change that was proposed. But no-one is arguing for the status quo. No-one can say that just keep on doing the same thing is good enough for Australia.

"What has occurred in recent times is now a much greater national awareness. We need to channel that into a national purpose to find the answers. The referendum was about listening to people and about getting better outcomes. And these principles will continue to guide me."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Last week was a slower one for all things related to economic data, but this week is more than making up for the shortfall. Here's what you can expect to see on the blog throughout the week, or if you want to jot down some dates in your diary (if you're that way inclined — no judgment here!) Monday 16/10: RBA assistant governor (financial system) Brad Jones discusses cryptocurrency and money in the digital age at the AFR's cryptocurrency summit in Sydney Tuesday 17/10: Minutes of RBA's October cash rate meeting are released (11:30am AEDT) Wednesday 18/10: RBA governor Michele Bullock speaks at the Australian Financial Security Authority summit in Sydney (9:30am AEDT); ABS releases building activity and latest births data (11:30am AEDT) Thursday 19/10: ABS releases unemployment data for September (11:30am AEDT); RBA releases annual report (after 3:30pm AEDT)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There has been widespread in-principle support for regulating cryptocurrency exchanges and digital asset platforms under the same rules that apply to other financial institutions. The Treasurer Jim Chalmers and Assistant Treasurer Stephen Jones today released a proposal paper that, among other things, recommends requiring crypto platform operators to hold an Australian Financial Services Licence. The government is also planning to implement some additional specific minimum standards for the sector around holding tokens, custody software and transactions. The government says the proposals are broadly in line with regulation in other countries and will give crypto investors better protections against financial loss resulting from the collapse of an exchange. BTC Markets CEO Caroline Bower said her company had already been positioning itself for such regulation. "Digital assets are so clearly the future of financial services. It is imperative the country keeps pace with our international peers, with a robust regulatory framework. "BTC Markets has long agitated for appropriate, proportional regulation of the crypto industry in Australia." The banking sector has also welcomed the move via its lobby group, the Australian Banking Association, whose CEO Anna Bligh said it was a welcome step in the fight against scams. "Almost half of scammed funds are currently being channelled into crypto, the getaway vehicle of choice for scammers," she said. "Once the stolen money reaches a crypto exchange, it is virtually impossible to recover. "This means no matter what financial services door a customer walks through, customers will be protected by the same regulatory standards." The government is inviting feedback on the proposal paper until December 1, with further consultation next year on the resulting draft legislation.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Banks, industry leaders welcome planned cryptocurrency regulation

children.content: There has been widespread in-principle support for regulating cryptocurrency exchanges and digital asset platforms under the same rules that apply to other financial institutions.
The
Treasurer Jim Chalmers and Assistant Treasurer Stephen Jones today released a proposal paper
that, among other things, recommends requiring crypto platform operators to hold an
Australian Financial Services Licence
The government is also planning to implement some additional specific minimum standards for the sector around holding tokens, custody software and transactions.

The government says the proposals are broadly in line with regulation in other countries and will give crypto investors better protections against financial loss resulting from the collapse of an exchange.
BTC Markets CEO Caroline Bower
said her company had already been positioning itself for such regulation.
"Digital assets are so clearly the future of financial services. It is imperative the country keeps pace with our international peers, with a robust regulatory framework.
"BTC Markets has long agitated for appropriate, proportional regulation of the crypto industry in Australia."
The banking sector has also welcomed the move via its lobby group, the
Australian Banking Association, whose CEO Anna Bligh
said it was a welcome step in the fight against scams.
"Almost half of scammed funds are currently being channelled into crypto, the getaway vehicle of choice for scammers," she said.
"Once the stolen money reaches a crypto exchange, it is virtually impossible to recover.
"This means no matter what financial services door a customer walks through, customers will be protected by the same regulatory standards."
The government is inviting
feedback on the proposal paper until December 1
, with further consultation next year on the resulting draft legislation.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you missed it earlier today, US-based miner Abermarle has dumped its $6.6 billion buyout bid for Liontown Resources, a lithium developer based in Western Australia. Abermarle says it decided to dump the bid because there were "growing complexities" around the transaction. The US miner's decision comes days after Hancock Prospecting, the iron ore miner controlled by Gina Rinehart, increased its stake in Liontown to 19.9% —which would have likely been enough to block Abermarle's takeover bid of $3 a share. "Our engagement with the Liontown team has been meaningful and productive. We appreciate the level of cooperation we have received, and we thank the entire team for their efforts," Albemarle CEO Kent Masters said in a statement. "That said, moving forward with the acquisition, at this time, is not in Albemarle's best interests ." Hancock Prospecting has not commented on the development. Liontown Resources entered a trading halt earlier this morning, shortly after making the announcement to the market. The company says the halt will remain in place until Liontown makes an announcement regarding the funding of its Kathleen Valley project, or Wednesday October 18 — whichever comes first. Reporting with Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ICYMI: Abermarle dumps $6.6 billion buyout bid for Liontown Resources

title.children: Pies lock in gun Freo forward as AFL trade period enters crucial final days

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Continuing our series looking at the draft class of 2023, and some of the names you will soon be very familiar with. Next up is Nate Caddy, perhaps the most eye-catching of this year's crop. With his glowing blonde hair and hulking frame, Caddy was impossible to miss on the field as he got around with Vic Metro and the Northern Knights. His footy backed up the attention though, as he starred as a mobile forward who could push up the ground and even have stints in midfield. Caddy's athletic gifts are obvious — his frame is massive, but he covers the ground exceptionally well — and his skills improved as the year progressed. Caddy has worked hard on his goalkicking in particular, and with his impressive tank and work rate is able to get up the field to make his presence felt while still rolling back to hit the scoreboard. He's still a bit untidy, a bit of a bull at a gate sometimes, but clubs will love his infectious energy. Expect Caddy to be a top 10 pick, and expect him to see AFL footy early in 2023 as his body is as ready as a first-year player's can get.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Draft Spotlight — Nate Caddy

(Getty Images)
His footy backed up the attention though, as he starred as a mobile forward who could push up the ground and even have stints in midfield.
Caddy's athletic gifts are obvious — his frame is massive, but he covers the ground exceptionally well — and his skills improved as the year progressed.

Caddy has worked hard on his goalkicking in particular, and with his impressive tank and work rate is able to get up the field to make his presence felt while still rolling back to hit the scoreboard.
(Getty Images)

He's still a bit untidy, a bit of a bull at a gate sometimes, but clubs will love his infectious energy. Expect Caddy to be a top 10 pick, and expect him to see AFL footy early in 2023 as his body is as ready as a first-year player's can get.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's done! They slipped that one in quietly, but it is all confirmed and signed off. Collingwood have traded pick 34 and a future first round pick to Fremantle for Lachie Schultz. A good deal for Fremantle you'd have to say, smart to back in Collingwood's first-round pick next year being lower than their 19 this year. Certainly can't get any worse. The Pies get their man and strengthen an already premiership-calibre forward line.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lachie Schultz has been traded to Collingwood

items.synopsis: In a statement the actress's publicist said she had an aggressive form of breast cancer.

title.children: Three's Company and Step by Step star Suzanne Somers dies a day before 77th birthday

image.altText: Amani Francois, Rekisha Satour and Conor Bowden.

items.synopsis: With six Australian states and territories delivering a resounding No vote to an Indigenous Voice to Parliament, young First Nations people reflect on what comes next.

title.children: 'This referendum will affect us the most': Young First Nations voters reflect on No vote

image.altText: X logo

items.synopsis: The Australian eSafety commission fines social media platform X, formerly known as Twitter, $610,500 for failing to cooperate with a probe into anti-child-abuse practices.

title.children: Platform X fined $610,500 over gaps in child abuse prevention

image.altText: Police leading a person away.

items.synopsis: Police allege a group was trafficking methylamphetamine throughout Shepparton and into Melbourne after arresting 15 people in coordinated raids throughout last week, also snaring imitation firearms and more than $50,000 in cash.

title.children: Imitation firearms seized, 15 arrested in string of drug busts netting more than $100k in meth

image.altText: A police van and blue gazebo behind a car park and police tape.

items.synopsis: Emergency crews were called to Trafalgar Avenue on Umina Beach around 3:15am after a man's body was found with stab wounds.

title.children: Man in custody after body found with stab wounds in beach carpark on NSW Central Coast

image.altText: A man is punched in the face during a UFC fight

items.synopsis: Everything is against Alex Volkanovski for his short-notice re-match with Islam Makhachev, but that is exactly how the UFC featherweight champion wants it.

title.children: Alex Volkanovski is walking the hardest path to UFC history and that's the point

image.altText: People on a beach in the foreground with a bushfire burning in the background.

items.synopsis: Four fires have intensified in the region as the RFS battles 72 fires statewide amid hot, dry and windy conditions.

title.children: 'Quite dangerous': Bushfires across northern NSW escalate amid extreme conditions and total fire bans
